[^0]:    ${ }^{16}$ The priority profile of Example 2 has an Ergin-cycle characterized by $\left(s, s^{\prime}\right)=\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right),(i, j, k)=(2,1,3), N_{s}=\{4\}$, and $N_{s^{\prime}}=\varnothing$.

frameworks, as many-to-one matching models with contracts (Hatfield and Milgrom, 2005) or many-to-many matching problems (Echenique and Oviedo, 2006). These extensions are of interest due to their potential applications to more complex labor or educational markets, such as school choice with affirmative action or part-time work assignments (e.g., medical interns in hospitals or teachers in public schools). However, to guarantee that a mechanism $\Phi$ is locally non-bossy using our approach, the following three properties are crucial: (i) $\Phi$ must be a stable mechanism; (ii) $\Phi$ must assign all students to the most/least preferred school they can attend in a stable matching; and (iii) any school that does not fill its quota in some stable matching must enroll the same set of students in any other stable outcome. Therefore, any attempt to extend our results to other contexts will likely require restricting the preference domain to ensure that properties analogous to (i)-(iii) hold. This is a matter for future research.

# APPENDIX A. LOCAL NON-BOSINESS AND ITS IMPLICATIONS 

Lemma 1. If $\Phi: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ is a locally non-bossy and strategy-proof mechanism, then it is locally group strategy-proof.

Proof. Given $P \in \mathcal{P}$ and $s \in S \cup\left\{s_{0}\right\}$, suppose that there is a coalition $C=\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{r}\right\}$ contained in $\Phi_{s}(P)$ such that $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) R_{i} \Phi_{i}(P)$ for all $i \in C$ and for some $P_{C}^{\prime}=\left(P_{j}^{\prime}\right)_{j \in C}$. We will prove that $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)=\Phi_{i}(P)$ for all $i \in C$.

For each $i \in \Phi_{s}(P)$, let $\widetilde{P}_{i}$ be the preference relation that places $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ at the top and keeps the other schools in the order induced by $P_{i}$. Suppose that $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P) \neq \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)$. The strategy-proofness of $\Phi$ implies that $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P) P_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)$ and $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right) \widetilde{P}_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}(P)$. If $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right) \neq \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, the definition of $\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}$ implies that $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right) P_{i} \Phi_{i_{1}}(P)$. Hence, $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P) P_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right) P_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}(P)$, which is not possible. As a consequence, $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P) \neq$ $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)$ ensures that $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)=\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, which in turn implies that $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P) P_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, a contradiction. We conclude that $\Phi_{i_{1}}(P)=\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)$, and the local non-bossiness of $\Phi$ implies that $\Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{-i_{1}}\right)$ for all $i \in \Phi_{s}(P)$. Repeating the argument for students $i_{2}, \ldots, i_{r}$ we obtain that $\Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(\widetilde{P}_{C}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in \Phi_{s}(P)$.

Since $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ is the most preferred alternative under $\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}$, it follows that $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) \widetilde{R}_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{C \backslash\{i\}}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) . \quad$ If $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) \neq \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{C \backslash\{i\}}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, then $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) \widetilde{P}_{i_{1}} \Phi_{i_{1}}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{C \backslash\{i\}}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, which contradicts the strategy-proofness of $\Phi$. Moreover, as $\Phi$ is locally non-bossy, $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)=\Phi_{i}\left(\widetilde{P}_{i_{1}}, P_{C \backslash\{i\}}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in \Phi_{s}(P)$. Repeating the argument for $i_{2}, \ldots, i_{r}$, we obtain that $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)=\Phi_{i}\left(\widetilde{P}_{C}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in \Phi_{s}(P)$. Therefore, $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)=\Phi_{i}(P)$ for every student $i \in C$.

In Example 4 we show that the converse of Lemma 1 does not hold.

Afacan (2012) introduces the following extension of non-bossiness to group of students: a mechanism $\Phi$ is group non-bossy when for any $P \in \mathcal{P}$ and $C \subseteq N$, if there exists $P_{C}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}^{|C|}$ such that $\Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in C$, then $\Phi(P)=\Phi\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$.

We will consider a local version of this property: a mechanism $\Phi$ is locally group non-bossy when for any $s \in S \cup\left\{s_{0}\right\}, P \in \mathcal{P}$, and $C \subseteq \Phi_{s}(P)$, if there exists $P_{C}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}^{|C|}$ such that $\Phi_{i}(P)=$ $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in C$, then $\Phi_{s}(P)=\Phi_{s}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$.

Hence, local group non-bossiness ensures that no coalition of students assigned to the same school can change the assignment of some of their colleagues by reporting different preferences, without changing their school.

Lemma 2. If $\Phi: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ is a locally non-bossy and strategy-proof mechanism, then it is locally group non-bossy.

Proof. Given $s \in S \cup\left\{s_{0}\right\}, P \in \mathcal{P}, C \subseteq \Phi_{s}(P)$, and $P_{C}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}^{|C|}$, suppose that $\Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $i \in C$. Since $\Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ ensures that $\Phi_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) R_{i} \Phi_{i}(P)$, the arguments made in the proof of Lemma 1 guarantee that $\Phi_{j}(P)=\Phi_{j}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$ for all $j \in \Phi_{s}(P)$. Hence, $\Phi_{s}(P) \subseteq$ $\Phi_{s}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$. Moreover, swapping the roles of $P$ and $\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$, we obtain $\Phi_{s}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right) \subseteq \Phi_{s}(P)$. Therefore, $\Phi_{s}(P)=\Phi_{s}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$.

The converse of Lemma 2 does not hold. Indeed, consider the Boston mechanism, also known as the Immediate Acceptance mechanism. This mechanism runs similarly to DA, with the difference that at each step accepted students are definitively matched to the school. Although it is not strategy-proof (Abdulkadiroğlu and Sönmez, 2003), it is locally group non-bossy. Formally, denoting by $\mathcal{B}: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ this mechanism, suppose that $\mathcal{B}_{i}(P)=\mathcal{B}_{i}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)=s$ for all student in a coalition $C \subseteq \mathcal{B}_{s}(P)$. Let $\widetilde{P}_{C}=\left(\widetilde{P}_{i}\right)_{i \in C}$ be such that $s$ is the most preferred alternative under each $\widetilde{P}_{i}$. It is not difficult to verify that $\mathcal{B}_{s}(P)=\mathcal{B}_{s}\left(\widetilde{P}_{C}, P_{-C}\right)=\mathcal{B}_{s}\left(P_{C}^{\prime}, P_{-C}\right)$.

In what follows, we present examples that allow us to relate local non-bossiness and other properties.

Example 3. A stable mechanism that is neither locally non-bossy nor strategy-proof.
Let $N=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\},\left(q_{s_{1}}, q_{s_{2}}\right)=(2,1), \succ_{s_{1}}: 1,2,3$, and $\succ_{s_{2}}: 3,2,1$.
Let $\bar{P}=\left(\bar{P}_{1}, \bar{P}_{2}, \bar{P}_{3}\right)$ be such that:

$$
\bar{P}_{1}: s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{0}, \quad \bar{P}_{2}: s_{2}, s_{1}, s_{0}, \quad \bar{P}_{3}: s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{0}
$$

Since the school-optimal stable mechanism in $[N, S, q, \succ, \bar{P}]$ is

$$
\mathrm{DA}^{S}(\bar{P})=\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right)\right)
$$

it differs from $\mathrm{DA}(\bar{P})=\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{2}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right)\right)$. Let $\Omega: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ be the stable mechanism such that $\Omega(P)=\mathrm{DA}(P)$ when $P \neq \bar{P}$, and $\Omega(\bar{P})=\mathrm{DA}^{S}(\bar{P})$.

We claim that $\Omega$ is locally bossy. Let $P_{1}$ be such that $P_{1}: s_{2}, s_{1}, s_{0}$. It is easy to see that $\Omega\left(P_{1}, \bar{P}_{-1}\right)=\mathrm{DA}\left(P_{1}, \bar{P}_{-1}\right)=\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{2}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right)\right)$. Since $\Omega\left(\bar{P}_{1}, \bar{P}_{-1}\right)=\mathrm{DA}^{S}(\bar{P})$, when student 1's preferences change from $P_{1}$ to $\bar{P}_{1}$, she remains assigned to $s_{1}$, but her schoolmates change as $\Omega_{s_{1}}\left(\bar{P}_{1}, \bar{P}_{-1}\right)=\{1,2\} \neq\{1,3\}=\Omega_{s_{1}}\left(P_{1}, \bar{P}_{-1}\right)$.

Since DA is the only stable and strategy-proof mechanism (Alcalde and Barberà, 1994), it follows that $\Omega$ does not satisfy strategy-proofness.

Since the Gale's Top Trading Cycles mechanism (Shapley and Scarf, 1974) is non-bossy and unstable, it follows from Example 3 that local non-bossiness and stability are independent properties.

Bando and Imamura (2016) introduce the following property: a mechanism $\Phi$ is weak non-bossy when for any $P \in \mathcal{P}, i \in N$, and $P_{i}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}, \Phi_{i}(P)=\Phi_{i}\left(P_{i}^{\prime}, P_{-i}\right)$ implies that $\Phi_{s_{0}}(P)=\Phi_{s_{0}}\left(P_{i}^{\prime}, P_{-i}\right)$. Hence, when a mechanism is weak non-bossy, no student can modify the set of unassigned students without changing her own school.

Since DA satisfies weak non-bossiness (Bando and Imamura, 2016; Theorem 3), it is interesting to compare it with local non-bossiness.

Lemma 3. Weak non-bossiness is independent of local non-bossiness and strategy-proofness.
Proof. On the one hand, it is not difficult to verify that the mechanism described in Example 3 is weak non-bossy. However, this mechanism is neither locally non-bossy nor strategy-proof. On the other hand, if $N=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\}$, and $\left(q_{s_{1}}, q_{s_{2}}\right)=(2,1)$, regardless of the schools' priority profile $\left(\succ_{s_{1}}, \succ_{s_{2}}\right)$, the mechanism $\Omega: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ that is defined by

$$
\Omega(P)= \begin{cases}\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right)\right), & \text { when } s_{2} P_{1} s_{1} \\ \left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{0}\right)\right), & \text { in another case }\end{cases}
$$

is locally non-bossy and strategy-proof but does not satisfy weak non-bossiness.

In one-to-one matching problems, local non-bossiness only requires that student without school cannot modify the set of unassigned students without getting a place elsewhere. Thus, weak non-bossiness is stronger than local non-bossiness in this context.

Although any group strategy.proof mechanism is weak non-bossy, it follows from the proof of Lemma 3 that the combination of local non-bossiness and strategy-proofness does not implies on weak non-bossiness.

Group strategy-proofness is stronger than group non-bossiness (Afacan, 2012). However, the following example shows that the analogous result does not hold for the local versions of these concepts.

Example 4. A locally group strategy-proof mechanism that is locally bossy and weak bossy.
Let $N=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\},\left(q_{s_{1}}, q_{s_{2}}\right)=(2,1), \succ_{s_{1}}: 1,2,3$, and $\succ_{s_{2}}: 3,1,2$.
Let $\Omega: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ be such that $\Omega(P)=\mathrm{DA}(P)$ unless the most preferred school of student 1 is $s_{1}$. In this case, let $\Omega_{1}(P)=s_{1}$ and $\Omega_{i}(P)=s_{0}$ for all $i \neq 1$. Notice that, since 1 has the highest priority at $s_{1}, \Omega_{1}(P) R_{1} s_{1}$ for all $P \in \mathcal{P}$.

The mechanism $\Omega$ is strategy-proof, because DA satisfies this property and no one can prevent 1 to receive a seat in $s_{1}$ when it is her most preferred alternative. Moreover, $\Omega$ is locally group strategy-proof. Indeed, if this were not the case, there would exist $P, P^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}$ and two students in $\Omega_{s_{1}}(P)=\{i, j\}$ such that if they report $\left(P_{i}^{\prime}, P_{j}^{\prime}\right)$ none of them would be worse off, and at least one of them strictly better off. Note that $s_{1}$ is not the most preferred school for student 1 under either $P_{1}$ (because in this case only one student is assigned to $s_{1}$ ) or $P_{1}^{\prime}$ (because otherwise at least one of the students $\{i, j\}$ is not assigned under $\left(P_{i}^{\prime}, P_{j}^{\prime}, P_{k}\right)$ and her situation worsens). Thus, $\Omega$ coincides with DA in the preference profiles $P$ and $\left(P_{i}^{\prime}, P_{j}^{\prime}, P_{k}\right)$. This contradicts the local group strategy-proofness of DA (see Theorem 1 and Lemma 1).

However, $\Omega$ is locally bossy. Consider the preference profile $P=\left(P_{1}, P_{2}, P_{3}\right)$ :

$$
P_{1}: s_{2}, s_{1}, s_{0}, \quad P_{2}: s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{0}, \quad P_{3}: s_{2}, s_{1}, s_{0}
$$

We have that $\Omega(P)=\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right)\right)$ and $\Omega_{s_{1}}(P)=\{1,2\}$. If the student 1 changes her preference to $P_{1}^{\prime}$ such that $P_{1}^{\prime}: s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{0}$, she remains assigned to $s_{1}$ but is left without schoolmates because $\Omega_{s_{1}}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}, P_{3}\right)=\{1\}$. This argument also shows that $\Omega$ is weak bossy, because $\Omega_{s_{0}}(P)=\varnothing$ and $\Omega_{s_{0}}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}, P_{3}\right)=\{2,3\}$.

Although the school-optimal stable mechanism is not strategy-proof, it is non-bossy (Afacan and Dur, 2017). Hence, the Example 4 implies that local non-bossiness and strategy-proofness are independent properties.

The last examples show that local group non-bossiness is stronger than local non-bossiness (Example 5), and than local group strategy-proofness is stronger that strategy-proofness (Example 6).

Example 5. A locally non-bossy mechanism that is not locally group non-bossy.
Let $N=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\},\left(q_{s_{1}}, q_{s_{2}}\right)=(3,1), \succ_{s_{1}}: 1,2,3$, and $\succ_{s_{2}}: 3,2,1$.
Denote by $\operatorname{top}\left(P_{i}\right)$ the most preferred alternative of student $i$ when her preferences are $P_{i} \in \mathcal{L}$. Let $\Omega: \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ be the mechanism such that:

$$
\Omega(P)= \begin{cases}\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right)\right), & \text { when } \operatorname{top}\left(P_{1}\right)=\operatorname{top}\left(P_{2}\right)=s_{1} \\ \left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right)\right), & \text { when } \operatorname{top}\left(P_{1}\right)=\operatorname{top}\left(P_{2}\right)=s_{2} \\ \left(\left(1, s_{0}\right),\left(2, s_{0}\right),\left(3, s_{0}\right)\right), & \text { in another case. }\end{cases}
$$

It is not difficult to verify that $\Omega$ is locally non-bossy: the only two students who might change their partners without changing schools are 1 and 2 . However, if only one of them changes her preferences, she will be assigned to $s_{0}$ (if she was originally assigned to $s_{1}$ or $s_{2}$ ), or will not change anyone's assigned school otherwise.

Moreover, $\Omega$ is locally group bossy. Let $P=\left(P_{1}, P_{2}, P_{3}\right)$ be a preference profile such that $\operatorname{top}\left(P_{1}\right)=\operatorname{top}\left(P_{2}\right)=s_{1}$ and consider $P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}$ such that $\operatorname{top}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}\right)=\operatorname{top}\left(P_{2}^{\prime}\right)=s_{2}$. Notice that, although $\Omega_{i}(P)=\Omega_{i}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}\right)=s_{1}$ for each student $i \in\{1,2\}$, we have that $\Omega_{s_{1}}(P)=\{1,2\} \neq\{1,2,3\}=\Omega_{s_{1}}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}\right)$.

Example 6. A strategy-proof mechanism that is not locally group strategy-proof.
Let $N=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\},\left(q_{s_{1}}, q_{s_{2}}\right)=(2,2), \succ_{s_{1}}: 1,2,3$, and $\succ_{s_{2}}: 3,2,1$.
Denote by $\operatorname{top}_{k}\left(P_{i}\right)$ the $k$-th most preferred alternative of student $i$ under $P_{i} \in \mathcal{L}$. Let $\Omega$ : $\mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}$ be the mechanism such that:

$$
\Omega(P)= \begin{cases}\left(\left(1, \operatorname{top}_{1}\left(P_{1}\right)\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right)\right), & \text { when } \operatorname{top}_{2}\left(P_{1}\right)=s_{2} \\ \left(\left(1, \operatorname{top}_{1}\left(P_{1}\right)\right),\left(2, s_{2}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right)\right), & \text { in another case. }\end{cases}
$$

It is easy to verify that $\Omega$ is strategy-proof. We claim that $\Omega$ is not locally group strategy-proof. Let $P=\left(P_{1}, P_{2}, P_{3}\right)$ be a preference profile such that $P_{1}: s_{1}, s_{2}, s_{0}$ and $P_{2}: s_{2}, s_{1}, s_{0}$. Let $P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}$ be such that $P_{1}^{\prime}: s_{1}, s_{0}, s_{2}$ and $P_{2}^{\prime}=P_{2}$. It follows that the coalition of schoolmates $\{1,2\} \in \Omega_{s_{1}}(P)$ can manipulate the mechanism $\Omega$ at $P$, because $\Omega_{1}(P)=s_{1}=\Omega_{1}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}\right)$ and $\Omega_{2}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}\right)=s_{2} P_{2} s_{1}=\Omega_{2}(P)$.

Example 7. The school-median stable matching is locally bossy.
Given a school choice problem $[N, S, \succ, q, P]$ with $k$ stable matchings, we refer to $\mu$ as the school-median stable matching when the following properties hold:

- If $k$ is odd, each student is assigned to her $(k+1) / 2$-th (weakly) best match among all $k$ stable matchings.
- If $k$ is even, each student is assigned to her $(k+2) / 2$-th (weakly) best match among all $k$ stable matchings.
Klaus and Klijn (2006, Theorem 3.2) ensure that this matching always exists.

We claim that the mechanism that associates to each preference profile the school-median stable matching is locally bossy. Let $N=\{1,2,3,4\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\}, q_{s_{1}}=q_{s_{2}}=2, \succ s_{1}: 2,1,3,4$, and $\succ s_{2}: 3,4,2,1$. If preferences are given by

$$
P_{1}: 2,1, \quad P_{2}: 2,1, \quad P_{3}: 1,2, \quad P_{4}=1,2
$$

there are three stable matchings:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu & =\left(\left(1, s_{2}\right),\left(2, s_{2}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right),\left(4, s_{1}\right)\right) \\
\eta & =\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{2}\right),\left(3, s_{1}\right),\left(4, s_{2}\right)\right) \\
\rho & =\left(\left(1, s_{1}\right),\left(2, s_{1}\right),\left(3, s_{2}\right),\left(4, s_{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that $\eta$ is the school-median stable matching. Now, if preferences of student 1 change to $P_{1}^{\prime}: 1,2$, the only stable matchings are $\eta$ and $\rho$. In this case, $\rho$ is the school-median stable matching. Therefore, as $\eta(1)=\rho(1)=s_{1}$ and $\eta\left(s_{1}\right) \neq \rho\left(s_{1}\right)$, we conclude that the school-median stable mechanism is locally bossy.

# APPENDIX B. OMITTED PROOFS 

Given a student $1 \in N$ and preference profiles $P, P^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}$, let $\mu=\mathrm{DA}\left(P_{1}, P_{-1}\right)$ and $\mu^{\prime}=\mathrm{DA}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{-1}\right)$. In the following results we characterize some properties of $\mu$ and $\mu^{\prime}$.

Lemma 4. Suppose that $\mu(1)=\mu^{\prime}(1)=\bar{s}$. If there exists $i \in N$ such that $s=\mu(i)$ and $s^{\prime}=\mu^{\prime}(i)$ are different, then $s \neq s_{0}, s^{\prime} \neq s_{0}$, and both schools fill their places in $\mu$ and $\mu^{\prime}$.

Proof. Let $\widehat{\mu}$ be the matching induced by $\mu$ when student 1 and one seat in $\bar{s}$ are eliminated (w.l.o.g., assume that $q_{s_{0}}=|N|$ ). Define $\widehat{\mu}^{\prime}$ analogously. Notice that $\widehat{\mu}$ and $\widehat{\mu}^{\prime}$ are stable matchings in the school choice problem $\left(N \backslash\{1\}, S,\left(\succ_{r}\right)_{r \in S},\left(\widehat{q}_{r}\right)_{r \in S}, P_{-1}\right)$ where $\widehat{q}_{\bar{s}}=q_{\bar{s}}-1$ and $\widehat{q}_{r}=q_{r}$ for $r \neq \bar{s}$. Since $s=\widehat{\mu}(i)$ and $s^{\prime}=\widehat{\mu}^{\prime}(i)$ are different, the Rural Hospital Theorem (Roth, 1986) implies that $s$ and $s^{\prime}$ are schools and fill their places in both $\widehat{\mu}$ and $\widehat{\mu}^{\prime}$. ${ }^{17}$ Therefore, $s$ and $s^{\prime}$ satisfy the same properties in $\mu$ and $\mu^{\prime}$.

Lemma 5. If $\mu^{\prime}(i) P_{i} \mu(i)$, then there exists a cycle $\left(i_{1}, \ldots i_{r}\right)$ that includes $i$ and satisfies:
(i) $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right)=\mu\left(i_{l+1}\right)$ for all $l \in\{1, \ldots, r\}[m o d u l o r]$.
(ii) $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right) P_{i_{l}} \mu\left(i_{l}\right)$ for all $l \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$.

Proof. Let $G^{*}=\left(V^{*}, E^{*}\right)$ be a multigraph in which $V^{*}=S$ and there is a directed edge between $s$ and $s^{\prime}$ for each student $k$ such that $\mu(k)=s$ and $\mu^{\prime}(k)=s^{\prime}$, with $s \neq s^{\prime}$. Since Lemma 4 ensures that $|\mu(s)|=q_{s}$ and $\left|\mu^{\prime}\left(s^{\prime}\right)\right|=q_{s^{\prime}}$ for any $s$ and $s^{\prime}$ such that $\left[s, s^{\prime}\right] \in E^{*}$, the in-degree and the out-degree of each node in $V^{*}$ coincide. Moreover, as schools $a=\mu(i)$ and $a^{\prime}=\mu^{\prime}(i)$ are different, there is at least one edge between $a$ and $a^{\prime}$.

As a consequence, there is a cycle of schools $\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{r}\right)$ in $G^{*}$ such that $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right)=\left(a, a^{\prime}\right)$. Indeed, we can form this cycle departing from node $a$ in direction to node $a^{\prime}$ and moving around the graph, because after enter a node $s_{j} \neq s_{1}$ from an edge, we are always able to exit from another edge. Since $V^{*}$ is a finite set, we will eventually return to $s_{1}$. The construction of $E^{*}$ allow us to associated to $\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{r}\right)$ a group of students $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{r}$ such that $i_{1}=i, \mu\left(i_{l}\right)=s_{l}$ for all $l \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$, and $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right)=s_{l+1}=\mu\left(i_{l+1}\right)$ for all $l \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$ [modulo $r$ ]. In particular, although $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{r}$ are not necessarily different, we can assume that the students $i_{1}, \ldots, i_{r}$ are.

Since $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right)=s_{l+1}$, when $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right) P_{i_{l}} \mu\left(i_{l}\right)$ the stability of $\mu$ ensures that $j \succ_{s_{l+1}} i_{l}$ for all $j \in$ $\mu\left(s_{l+1}\right)$. Hence, the stability of $\mu^{\prime}$ implies that any edge between $s_{l+1}$ and $s_{l+2}$ is associated to a student that improves we she moves from $\mu$ to $\mu^{\prime}$. In particular, $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l+1}\right) P_{i_{l+1}} \mu\left(i_{l+1}\right)$. Therefore, $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{1}\right) P_{i_{1}} \mu\left(i_{1}\right)$ ensures that $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{l}\right) P_{i_{l}} \mu\left(i_{l}\right)$ for all $l \in\{1, \ldots, r\}$.

We conclude that $\left(i_{1}, \ldots, i_{r}\right)$ satisfies properties (i) and (ii).

Lemma 6. Suppose that $|N|=\sum_{s \in S} q_{s}, P \in \mathcal{P}^{*}$, and $\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{-1}\right) \in \mathcal{P}^{*}$. If $\mu(1) \neq \mu^{\prime}(1)$, then $\operatorname{Coll}_{1}(P) \cap \operatorname{Coll}_{1}\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{-1}\right)=\varnothing$.

Proof. Since $|N|=\sum_{s \in S} q_{s}$ and everyone considers all schools admissible under the preference profiles $P$ and $\left(P_{1}, P_{-1}\right)$, it follows that $\tilde{s} \equiv \mu(1)$ and $\tilde{s} \equiv \mu^{\prime}(1)$ are two different schools. By contradiction, suppose that there exists $i_{1} \in N \backslash\{1\}$ such that $\mu\left(i_{1}\right)=\tilde{s}$ and $\mu^{\prime}\left(i_{1}\right)=\tilde{s}$. Without loss of generality, assume that $\tilde{s} P_{i_{1}} \tilde{s}$ (in other case, exchange the roles of $P$ and $\left.\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{-1}\right)\right)$.

In the proof of Theorem 1, the fact that $\mu(1)=\mu^{\prime}(1)$ is only used to guarantee that all students who have different assignments in $\mu$ and $\mu^{\prime}$ are assigned to schools and these schools fill their quota (see Lemma 4). In the current context, although $\mu(1) \neq \mu^{\prime}(1)$, the same properties hold because DA is a stable mechanism, $|N|=\sum_{s \in S} q_{s}$, and preference profiles belong to $\mathcal{P}^{*}$.

Thus, after assuming the existence of $i_{1} \neq 1$ such that $\mu\left(i_{1}\right)=\tilde{s}, \mu^{\prime}\left(i_{1}\right)=\tilde{s}$, and $\tilde{s} P_{i_{1}} \tilde{s}$, the same arguments made in the proof of Theorem 1 ensure that $\mu(\tilde{s}) \backslash\{1\}=\mu^{\prime}(\tilde{s}) \backslash\{1\}$. Since $i_{1} \in \mu(\tilde{s}) \backslash\{1\}$, we conclude that $\tilde{s}=\tilde{s}$. A contradiction.

Proof of Theorem 2. Given a priority profile $\succ$, the stability of $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$ ensures that it is individually rational and weakly non-wasteful. $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$ is also population-monotonic (Crawford, 1991), strategy-proof (Dubins and Freedman, 1981; Roth, 1982), and weakly WrARP because under deferred acceptance each school chooses the students according to its priority order. The weak local non-bossiness of $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$ follows from Theorem 1.

Suppose that $\Phi: \mathcal{N} \times \mathcal{P} \rightarrow \mathcal{M}^{*}$ satisfies individual rationality (IR), weak non-wastefulness (WNW), population-monotonicity (PM), strategy-proofness (SP), weak WrARP (w-WrARP), and weak local non-bossiness (WLNB).

Given $s \in S$, let $P^{s}$ be a preference relation such that $s$ is the only admissible school. Denote by $\bar{P}=\left(\bar{P}_{i}\right)_{i \in \bar{N}}$ a preference profile such that $\bar{P}_{i}=P^{s}$ for every $i \in \bar{N}$. It follows from WNW that the mapping that associates to each $N \in \mathcal{N}$ the set $\Phi_{s}(N, \bar{P})$ is a choice function. ${ }^{18}$ Moreover, WNW, PN, w-WrARP, and the Theorem 2 of Chambers and Yenmez (2018) guarantee that there exists a priority order $\succ_{s}$ defined on $\bar{N}$ such that the following property holds:

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{18}$ A choice function is a mapping $C: \mathcal{N} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}$ such that, for each $N \in \mathcal{N}, C(N)$ is a non-empty subset of $N$.

(A) For each $N \in \mathcal{N}$, if $i \in N \backslash \Phi_{s}(N, \bar{P})$, then $j \succ_{s} i$ for all $j \in \Phi_{s}(N, \bar{P})$.
Let $\succ=\left(\succ_{s}\right)_{s \in S}$. We will use the property (A) to show that $\Phi=\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$.
By contradiction, assume that there is $N^{*} \in \mathcal{N}$ such that $\Phi\left(N^{*}, \cdot\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, \cdot\right)$. For each $(N, P) \in \mathcal{N} \times \mathcal{P}$, let $Z(N, P)=|\left\{i \in N:\left|A\left(P_{i}\right)\right| \leq 1\right\}|$ be the number of students in $N$ who find at most one school admissible. Let $P^{*} \in \mathcal{P}$ be such that $\Phi\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$ and $Z\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) \geq Z\left(N^{*}, P\right)$ for all $P \in \mathcal{P}$ satisfying $\Phi\left(N^{*}, P\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P\right)$. Given $i \in N^{*}$, we claim that $\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$ implies that $\left|A\left(P_{i}^{*}\right)\right|=1$. There are two cases to analyze:

- Case 1: $\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$. Since $\Phi$ and $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$ satisfy IR, $s:=\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$ belongs to $S$. Hence, $\left|A\left(P_{i}^{*}\right)\right| \geq 1$. IR and SP imply that $\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i}^{*}\right)\right)=s$ and $\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i}^{*}\right)\right)=s_{0}$. As a consequence, if $\left|A\left(P_{i}^{*}\right)\right|>1$, we obtain that $Z\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i}^{*}\right)\right)>Z\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$ and $\Phi\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i}^{*}\right)\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}^{\succ}\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i}^{*}\right)\right)$, which contradicts the definition of $P^{*}$. Therefore, $\left|A\left(P_{i}^{*}\right)\right|=1$.
- Case 2: $\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$. The result follows from the same arguments applied in the previous case but swapping the roles of $\Phi$ and $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$.

Let $i \in N^{*}$ be such that $\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) \neq \mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$. Since $\left|A\left(P_{i}^{*}\right)\right|=1$, it follows from IR that there exists $s \in S$ such that either $s=\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$ or $s=\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$. Furthermore, without loss of generality, IR and SP allows us to assume that $P_{i}^{*}=P^{s}$.

When $s=\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$, WNW implies that $\left|\Phi_{s}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)\right|=q_{s}$. Let $\Phi_{s}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{q_{s}}\right\}$, where $i_{1} \succ_{s} \cdots \succ_{s} i_{q_{s}}$. Since IR and SP ensure that $\Phi_{i_{1}}\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i_{1}}^{*}\right)\right)=s$, it follows from WLNB that $\Phi_{s}\left(N^{*},\left(P^{s}, P_{-i_{1}}^{*}\right)\right)=\Phi_{s}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)$. Applying this argument to $i_{2}, \ldots, i_{q_{s}}$, we conclude that there is no loss of generality in assuming that $P_{j}^{*}=P^{s}$ for all $j \in \Phi_{s}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) .{ }^{19}$ Let $N=\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{q_{s}}, i\right\}$. Since $P_{i}^{*}=P^{s}, N \subseteq N^{*}$, and $\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=s$, it follows from PM that $\mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N, P^{*}\right)=s$. Moreover, the fact that $P_{N}^{*}=$ $\left(P^{s}, \ldots, P^{s}\right)$ and the definition of $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$ guarantee that $\mathrm{DA}_{i_{0}}^{\succ}\left(N, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$ and $i \succ_{s} i_{q_{s}}$. On the other hand, since $N \subseteq N^{*}$ and $\Phi_{s}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=N \backslash\{i\}$, PM implies that $\Phi_{s}\left(N, P^{*}\right)=N \backslash\{i\}$. ${ }^{20}$ Hence, $\Phi_{i}\left(N, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$ and the property (A) guarantees that $i_{q_{s}} \succ_{s} i$. A contradiction.

When $s=\Phi_{i}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right) P_{i}^{*} \mathrm{DA}_{i}^{\succ}\left(N^{*}, P^{*}\right)=s_{0}$, we can obtain a contradiction applying the arguments of the previous paragraph but swapping the roles of $\Phi$ and $\mathrm{DA}^{\succ}$.

Independence of the axioms in Theorem 2. The independence of individual rationality, weak non-wastefulness, population monotonicity, and strategy-proofness is shown in Ehlers and Klaus (2016) through several examples. Since these examples satisfy weakly WrARP and weakly local non-bossiness, they also show that there exist mechanisms that satisfy all the axioms of Theorem 2 except for one of the following: individual rationality, weak non-wastefulness, population monotonicity, or strategy-proofness. Hence, to ensure the independence of the axioms in Theorem 2, it suffices to show that there are mechanisms that satisfy all the axioms but either weakly WrARP or weakly local non-bossiness.

Example 8. All the axioms are satisfied but weakly WrARP.
Let $\bar{N}=\{1,2,3,4\}, S=\{s\}$ and $q_{s}=2$. Consider the profile $\bar{P}$ such that $s \bar{P}_{i} s_{0}$ for all $i \in \bar{N}$ and the mechanism $\Phi$ such that:

$$
\Phi_{s}(\{1,2,3\}, \bar{P})=\{1,3\}, \quad \Phi_{s}(\{1,2,4\}, \bar{P})=\{2,4\}
$$

Moreover, for other $N$ and $P$, assume that $\Phi_{s}(N, P)$ is computed using the serial dictatorship according to the order $(1,2,3,4) .{ }^{21}$

Example 9. All the axioms are satisfied but weakly local non-bossiness.
Let $\bar{N}=\{1,2,3\}, S=\left\{s_{1}, s_{2}\right\}, q_{s_{1}}=2$, and $q_{s_{2}}=1$.
Consider the profiles $P^{\prime}=\left(P_{1}^{\prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}^{\prime}\right)$ and $P^{\prime \prime}=\left(P_{1}^{\prime \prime}, P_{2}^{\prime}, P_{3}^{\prime}\right)$, where

$$
P_{1}^{\prime}: s_{1}, s_{2}, \quad P_{1}^{\prime \prime}: s_{2}, s_{1}, \quad P_{2}^{\prime}: s_{1}, s_{2}, \quad P_{3}^{\prime}: s_{1}, s_{2}
$$

Let $\Phi$ be the mechanism such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi_{s_{1}}\left(\{1,2,3\}, P^{\prime}\right) & =\{1,2\}, & \Phi_{s_{2}}\left(\{1,2,3\}, P^{\prime}\right)=\{3\} \\
\Phi_{s_{1}}\left(\{1,2,3\}, P^{\prime \prime}\right) & =\{1,3\}, & \Phi_{s_{2}}\left(\{1,2,3\}, P^{\prime \prime}\right)=\{2\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, for other $N$ and $P$, assume that $\Phi(N, P)$ is computed using the serial dictatorship according to the order $(1,2,3)$.

abstract:
The student-optimal stable mechanism (DA), the most popular mechanism in
school choice, is the only one that is stable and strategy-proof. However, when
DA is implemented, a student can change the schools of others without changing
her own. We show that this drawback is limited: a student cannot change her
schoolmates while remaining in the same school. We refer to this new property
as local non-bossiness and use it to provide a new characterization of DA that
does not rely on stability. Furthermore, we show that local non-bossiness plays
a crucial role in providing incentives to be truthful when students have
preferences over their colleagues. As long as students first consider the
school to which they are assigned and then their schoolmates, DA induces the
only stable and strategy-proof mechanism. There is limited room to expand this
preference domain without compromising the existence of a stable and
strategy-proof mechanism.
